text:
[[Argument]] is a series of [[statements|Propositions]] referred to as [[Premises|Premise]], followed by a final [[statement|Propositions]] referred to as the [[Conclusion]]. A [[deductive]] [[Argument]] can either be [[Valid|Valid Argument]] or [[Invalid]]. The concept of [[Argument]] can be easily confused with that of [[Conditional Proposition]]. And indeed, for each argument, a corresponding proposition can be constructed: [[Premises|Premise]] correspond to [[Antecedents|Antecedent]], and the [[Conclusion]] corresponds to the [[Consequent]]. But it's different in that [[Arguments|Argument]] aren't [[Truth Functions|Truth Function]] and don't have [[Truth Value]]. Arguments aren't [[Propositions]] - they are //"vectors"// of propositions. The syntax diagram of an argument looks like:
<> And the syntax diagram of the corresponding [[Conditional Proposition]] looks like:
<> [[|Premise]] [[|Conjunction]] [[|Material Implication]] [[|Conclusion]] [[|Logical Consequence]]
title: Argument
